profileText: A Delegate from the Territory of Utah and a Senator from Utah; born in Salt Lake City, Utah, January 25, 1859; attended the public schools, and graduated from the University of Utah at Salt Lake City in 1878; newspaper writer; moved to San Francisco, Calif., in 1880 and worked as a newspaper reporter; moved to Ogden, Utah, in 1882, and served as deputy county clerk and recorder; elected county recorder in 1884; became editor of the Ogden Herald in 1887 and established the Ogden Standard in 1888; unsuccessful candidate for election in 1892 to the Fifty-third Congress; interested in the building of the Ogden Canyon electric power plant in 1893; elected as a Republican to the Fifty-fourth Congress and served from March 4, 1895, to January 4, 1896, when the Territory was admitted as a State into the Union; was then elected as a Republican to the United States Senate and served from January 22, 1896, to March 3, 1899; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1898; affiliated with the Democratic Party in 1900 and served as State chairman 1902-1904; again became interested in newspaper publishing and established the Daily Utah State Journal at Ogden in 1903; moved to Denver, Colo., in 1909, and engaged in newspaper work and mining; died in Denver, Colo., July 25, 1933; interment in Ogden City Cemetery, Ogden, Utah.

note.content: Served until January 4, 1896, when the Territory of Utah was granted statehood; subsequently elected Senator from the new State.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Cannon, Frank Jenne, and Harvey J. O'Higgins. Under the Prophet in Utah: The National Menace of a Political Priestcraft. Boston: C.M. Clark Publishing Co., 1911.
Schlup, Leonard. "Utah Maverick: Frank J. Cannon and the Politics of Conscience." Utah Historical Quarterly 63 (Fall 1994): 335-48.
Cannon, Frank Jenne, and George Leonard Knapp. Brigham Young and His Mormon Empire. New York: Fleming H. Revell Co., 1913.
Lyman, Edward Leo. "Statehood, Political Allegiance, and Utah's First Senate Seats: Prizes for the National Parties and Local Factions." Utah Historical Quarterly 63 (Fall, 1995): 341-56.

creativeWork.name: Holley, Val. Frank J. Cannon: Saint, Senator, Scoundrel. Salt Lake City: University of Utah Press, 2020.
creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Holley, Val. Frank J. Cannon: Saint, Senator, Scoundrel. Salt Lake City: University of Utah Press, 2020.

researchRecord.name: 1929-1933. Ca. 2,050 items. Correspondence, news releases, press statements, notes, and publications chiefly relating to Cannon's promotion of free silver and the remonetization of silver while president of the Bimetallic Association and chairman of International Silver Commission. Finding aid.
17 audiotapes (1973-1975) in Westinghouse Broadcasting Company collection, 1945-1981.
